layoutData.title: 7 Key Components of Every Lease Agreement
paragraphs: A lease is a legally binding contract. Read every word before signing‚Äîyou're agreeing to follow these terms for the entire lease duration.
bulletPoints: Names & Addresses: All tenants listed, property address, landlord contact info
Rent Details: Amount, due date, payment methods, late fees, grace periods
Security Deposit: Amount, refund conditions, timeline, deduction policies
Lease Duration: Start/end dates, renewal options, early termination fees
Policies & Rules: Pets, guests, noise, smoking, alterations allowed
Entry Rights: When landlord can enter (usually 24-48 hour notice required)

content.headerTitle: Lease Red Flags to Watch For

leftPanel.title: Warning Signs in Lease Agreements
paragraphs: Not all leases are created equal. Some contain clauses that could cost you money or limit your rights. Be cautious if you see:
Vague language about when or how security deposits will be returned.
Unclear maintenance responsibilities that could leave you paying for repairs.
Excessive fees for basic services or common situations.

highlightBox.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Never sign a lease that requires you to waive legal rights or contains clauses that violate tenant protection laws.

leftPanel.title: What You'll Pay Before Move-In
paragraphs: Moving into a rental requires significant upfront investment‚Äîoften 3-4 months of rent before you ever unpack a box.

layoutData.title: Beyond Just the Rent Payment
paragraphs: Your monthly rent is just the base cost. Your true monthly housing expense includes many additional items that can add $200-$500+ to your budget.

keyPoint.text: üí° Always ask "What's included in rent?" and budget 25-35% extra for utilities and fees.

leftPanel.title: Costs That Surprise New Renters
paragraphs: Even careful budgeters can be caught off guard by fees and costs that aren't obvious upfront.
Late payment fees are typically 5-10% of your rent‚Äîa $1,200 rent could mean a $60-$120 late fee.
Annual rent increases of 3-5% are standard. A $1,200 apartment could be $1,260 next year.
Early termination fees if you need to break your lease are often 2-3 months' rent.

highlightBox.text: � Ask about ALL fees before signing. Get a complete list in writing.

leftColumn.title: ‚úì Advantages
items: No property taxes or HOA fees

leftPanel.title: Your Legal Protections as a Renter
paragraphs: As a tenant, you have legal rights that protect you from unfair treatment. These vary by state but generally include:
Right to Habitable Housing: Your rental must be safe, clean, and in good repair with working utilities.
Right to Privacy: Landlords must give proper notice (usually 24-48 hours) before entering, except in emergencies.
Right to Security Deposit Protection: Laws regulate how deposits are held and returned.

highlightBox.text: ‚öñÔ∏è If your landlord violates your rights, document everything and know how to file complaints with local housing authorities.

scenario.name: Emma's First Apartment in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Emma recently graduated from college and moved to a new city for her first job. She found a one-bedroom apartment for $1,200/month in a convenient location near work.

layoutData.title: Being a Good Tenant = Protecting Yourself
paragraphs: Fulfilling your responsibilities as a tenant protects your deposit, your rental history, and your ability to rent in the future. Landlords share references.
bulletPoints: Pay Rent on Time: Late payments = fees + negative rental history
Maintain the Property: Keep it clean, don't cause damage beyond normal wear
Report Problems Promptly: Small issues become big (expensive) problems
Follow Lease Terms: Pets, guests, noise‚Äîviolations can lead to eviction
Provide Proper Notice: Usually 30-60 days before moving out
Allow Reasonable Access: Let landlord in for repairs/inspections with notice
